analyzed: avara daurbalyāt na varaḥ avaraḥ nikṛṣṭaḥ dveṣa ādi abhibhūtaḥ aparamārtha jñānaḥ iti arthaḥ tasya daurbalyāt dharma adharma parijñāna aśakteḥ iti arthaḥ
translated: Because of the weakness of the inferior, the inferior is the worst, overwhelmed by hatred and so on, meaning one who does not know the ultimate truth. The meaning is that because of his weakness, he is unable to know dharma and adharma.

original: etaccānena jñāpitaṃ bhavati mahatāmapi tadvidāṃ kadā cidabhibhavo 'stīti /
analyzed: etat ca anena jñāpitam bhavati mahatām api tad vidām kadā cid abhibhavaḥ sti iti
translated: And this is indicated by him: even great knowers of that [truth] are sometimes overwhelmed.

analyzed: śarīravataḥ priya apriyayoḥ avaśyaṃbhāvi tvāt
translated: Because for one who has a body, pleasure and pain are necessarily present.

analyzed: tasmāt yāvat eteṣām rāga ādi doṣeṇa abhibhavaḥ
translated: Therefore, as long as they are overwhelmed by the faults of passion and so on,

analyzed: tāvat teṣām ācāraḥ na grāhyaḥ
translated: even their conduct should not be accepted.

analyzed: tathā ca vasiṣṭhaḥ śiṣṭaḥ punar a kāma ātmā iti
translated: And thus Vasistha says: The virtuous one, moreover, is one who is free from desire.

analyzed: athavā avara śabdena idānīṃtanāḥ kali yuga puruṣāḥ ucyante
translated: Or else, by the word inferior the people of the present Kali age are meant.

analyzed: teṣām daurbalyāt a sārmathyāt
translated: Because of their weakness, their inability.

original: evaṃ smṛtipramāṇamuktvā adhunā ekārthopanipatitānāṃ vākyānāṃ parasparavirodhe sati kiṃ kravyamityāta āha
analyzed: evam smṛti pramāṇam uktvā adhunā eka artha upanipatitānām vākyānām paraspara virodhe sati kim kravyam iti ā atas āha
translated: Having thus stated the authority of Smriti, now, when there is mutual contradiction among the statements that have come together with the same meaning, what should be done? Therefore it is said:

analyzed: tulya bala virodhe vikalpaḥ
translated: In the case of contradiction between equally authoritative statements, there is an option.

analyzed: tulya pramāṇa prāpitaḥ padārthaḥ tulya balaḥ
translated: An object reached by equally authoritative means of knowledge is of equal strength.

analyzed: tayoḥ paraspara virodhe sati vikalpaḥ veditavyaḥ
translated: When there is mutual contradiction between them, an option should be understood.

analyzed: ayam vā ayam vā iti
translated: This or that.

analyzed: na ubhaya parityāgaḥ
translated: Not the abandonment of both.

analyzed: ubhayoḥ pramāṇa prāpita tvāt
translated: Because both are established by valid means of knowledge.

analyzed: na anyatara parigrahaḥ  ekasmin gṛhyamāṇe dvitīyasya ānarthakya prasaṅgaḥ syāt iti
translated: Not the acceptance of one.🔽If one is accepted, the other would be purposeless.

analyzed: kim udāharaṇam śrutau tāvat udite hotavyam
translated: What is the example? First, in the Veda: One should offer when the sun has risen.

analyzed: an udite hotavyam iti evamādi
translated: One should offer before the sun has risen. And so on.

analyzed: smṛtau api nityam abhojyam keśa kīṭa avapannam iti gautamaḥ  pakṣi jagdham gavā āghrātam avadhūtam avakṣutam
translated: In the Smriti also: Gautama says that what is defiled by hair and insects should never be eaten.🔽What is eaten by birds, smelt by cows, shaken, or sneezed at,

analyzed: dūṣitam keśa kīṭaiḥ ca mṛd prakṣepeṇa śudhyati
translated: Defiled by hair and insects is purified by throwing away the earth.

analyzed: iti manuḥ
translated: This is Manu.

original: nanucātra sārmathyādeva vikalpaprasiddheḥ anarthakamidaṃ sūtraṃ samuccayastāvadatra na saṃbhatīti /
analyzed: nanu ca atra sārmathyāt eva vikalpa prasiddheḥ anarthakam idam sūtram samuccayaḥ tāvat atra na
translated: But since the option is well-known from the very context here, this aphorism is purposeless. The combination is not possible here.

original: na hyanudite hutvā punarudite hotuṃ śakyate /
analyzed: na hi an udite hutvā punar udite hotum śakyate
translated: For having offered when the sun has not risen, it is not possible to offer again when the sun has risen.

analyzed: guṇa bhūta kāla vaśena pradhānasya homasya āvṛtteḥ anyāyya tvāt  pradhāna vaśa vartinaḥ hi guṇāḥ
translated: Because it is not proper for the principal, the offering, to be repeated due to the subordinate time.🔽For the subordinate factors are subject to the principal.

analyzed: na guṇa vaśa varti pradhānam iti
translated: The principal is not subject to the subordinate.

analyzed: na ca anāvṛttam ubhayoḥ kālayoḥ hetum śakyate
translated: And it cannot be said to be the cause of both times without being repeated.

analyzed: evam smṛtau api samuccayaḥ sambhavati iti
translated: Thus, in Smṛti also, combination is possible by the principles of purification and abandonment.

analyzed: paraspara virodhāt iti
translated: Due to mutual contradiction.

analyzed: na ca ubhaya parityāgaḥ yuktaḥ iti uktam
translated: And it has been said that the abandonment of both is not proper.

analyzed: tena atra vikalpaḥ eva prāpnoti iti na arthaḥ nena iti
translated: Therefore, here option alone is obtained. So this has no purpose.

analyzed: evam tarhi nyāya prāpta anuvādaḥ yam viśeṣa arthaḥ
translated: If so, then this is a special statement repeating what is obtained by reasoning.

analyzed: kaḥ viśeṣaḥ tulya balayoḥ eva virodhe vikalpaḥ
translated: What is the difference? In the case of two equally strong [factors], there is option in contradiction.

original: atulyabalayostu bādha eveti /🔽tena śrutismṛtyorvirodhe smṛtireva bādhyate /
analyzed: atulya balayoḥ tu bādhaḥ eva iti  tena śruti smṛtyoḥ virodhe smṛtiḥ eva bādhyate
translated: But in the case of unequal strength, there is only sublation.🔽Therefore, in the case of contradiction between Śruti and Smṛti, only Smṛti is sublated.

analyzed: śrutau hi pratyakṣaḥ śabdaḥ smṛtau ānumānikaḥ
translated: For in Śruti the word is directly perceived, while in Smṛti it is inferred.

analyzed: na ca anumānam pratyakṣa virodhe pramāṇībhavati
translated: And inference is not a valid means of knowledge when contradicting direct perception.

original: evaṃ smṛtyācāravirodhe ca mātuladuhitṛpariṇayanādyācāro bādhyata iti /
analyzed: evam smṛti ācāra virodhe ca mātula duhitṛ pariṇayana ādi ācāraḥ bādhyate iti
translated: Similarly, in the case of contradiction between Smṛti and practice, the practice of marrying one's mother's sister's daughter and so on is sublated.

analyzed: tatra hi ācārāt smṛti anumānam iti
translated: For there, the inference of Smṛti is from practice.

analyzed: virodhe vikalpa vacanāt
translated: In case of contradiction, because of the statement of option.

original: avirodhe tu tulyapramāṇaśiṣṭānāṃ samuccayaḥ yathā ācamanādīnāṃ śrauteṣu karmasviti //
analyzed: avirodhe tu tulya pramāṇa śiṣṭānām samuccayaḥ yathā ācamana ādīnām śrauteṣu karmasu iti
translated: But in the absence of contradiction, there is combination of those instructed by equally authoritative sources, like the Ācamana and other [rules], in the Vedic rites.

original: nanu ca yadi vedaliṅgaprabhavatvābhyupagama eva smṛteḥ śrutyā sahātulyabalatvamupapādyate /🔽tadā hi mantrārthavādavākyeṣvanyapareṣvapi yāni smārtadharmamabalabhūtāni liṅgānikumārā
analyzed: nanu ca yadi veda liṅga prabhava tva abhyupagamaḥ eva smṛteḥ śrutyā saha atulya balatvam upapādyate  tadā hi mantra arthavāda vākyeṣu anya pareṣu api yāni smārta dharmam abala bhūtāni
translated: But if the equal strength of Smṛti with Śruti is explained only on the basis of accepting that Smṛti originates from the indications of the Veda,🔽then in the case of mantra and arthavāda sentences that are about other things, the indications that are weaker in the Smṛti dharma

original: viśikhā ivaityevamādīni teṣāṃ pratyakṣavedavākyavirodhe sati virodhivākyānumānavirodhāt🔽durbalatvaṃ prasajyate /
analyzed: viśikhāḥ iva eti evamādīni teṣām pratyakṣa veda vākya virodhe sati virodhi vākya anumāna virodhāt  durbala tvam prasajyate
translated: If the fact of the Smṛti being of equal strength with the Veda is sought to be proved by the circumstance of its having its source in Vedic texts, then, in that case, in the case of the Mantra and Arthavāda texts of the Veda also, which are not of the nature of injunctions, there are certain words which serve the same purpose as the Smṛti texts do, and which are as much incapable of being construed with the injunctive passages as the Smṛti texts are; for instance, in the Mantra passage ‘Kṣattā vrīhiyavena, etc.’ (Taittirīya Samhitā, 1.5.8.1), the word ‘vrīhi’ (‘barley’) is not connected with the injunction of the sacrificial post, yet it is not on that account that this Mantra passage is regarded as not having the capacity to bring about the knowledge of the post; in the same manner, in the case of the Arthavāda passages also, even though the words are not directly connected with the injunctive passages, yet there is nothing incongruous in their being construed along with these latter.

original: yadā tūtsannaśākhāpūrvikā smṛtirabhyupagameyathā'hāpastambaḥbrāhmaṇoktā vidhayasteṣāmutsannāḥ pāṭhāḥ prayogādanumīyanteiti tadobhayośca 🔽vaidikatvāt tulyabalataiva prasajyate /🔽na hyanumitasya vedavākyasya pratyakṣasya ca balābalaviśeṣo 'sti pratyakṣānumānaparicchinnāgnivaditi /
analyzed: yadā tu utsanna śākhā pūrvikā smṛtiḥ abhyupagame yathā āha āpastambaḥ brāhmaṇa uktāḥ vidhayaḥ teṣām utsannāḥ pāṭhāḥ prayogāt anumīyante iti tadā ubhayoḥ ca  vaidika tvāt tulya bala tā eva prasajyate  na hi anumitasya veda vākyasya pratyakṣasya ca bala abala viśeṣaḥ sti pratyakṣa anumāna paricchinna agni vat iti
translated: If, on the other hand, the Smṛti is held to be based upon such Vedic passages as have become lost, then, in that case, both the Smṛti and the Vedic passages would be of equal strength, and there would be nothing to choose between them; and in that case, the Smṛti could not be rejected merely on the ground of its being Smṛti.

original: syādetat yatra smṛtivacane vedavirodho 'sti tannaiva vedavākyānumāpakaṃ bhavati /🔽kiṃ tarhi bhrāntyādiprabhavamevaitaditi /
analyzed: syāt etat yatra smṛti vacane veda virodhaḥ sti tat nā eva veda vākya anumāpakam bhavati 🔽kim tarhi bhrānti ādi prabhavam eva etat iti
translated: Because there is no difference in the strength or weakness of the Vedic passage inferred from the Smṛti and the Vedic passage directly perceived. Just as in the case of the inference of fire from the perception of smoke, the inferred fire is not different from the fire perceived directly.

analyzed: tat ca na yuktam
translated: And that is not proper.

analyzed: dharma śāstra praṇetuḥ anāpta tva abhyupagame aviśvāsa prasaṅgāt
translated: Because if the author of the Dharma Shastra is accepted as untrustworthy, then there would be a danger of disbelief.

original: yadāpi vedavadavicchinnapāraṃparyeṇāgatā smṛtirabhyupagamyate tadāpi tulyabalatvamupapadyata iti tatrāpi tannaivopapadyate /
analyzed: yadā api veda vat avicchinna pāraṃparyeṇa āgatā smṛtiḥ abhyupagamyate tadā api tulya bala tvam upapadyate iti tatra api tat na eva upapadyate
translated: Even when Smriti is accepted as coming through an unbroken tradition like the Vedas, then also the equality of strength is possible. Therefore, that is not proper even there.

original: yastāvanmātuladuhitṛpariṇayanādikaḥ samācāra upanyastaḥ sa kāmādyabhibhave sati duṣṭācāratvācchiṣṭācāra eva nopapadyate /
analyzed: yaḥ tāvat mātula duhitṛ pariṇayana ādikaḥ samācāraḥ upanyastaḥ sa kāma ādi abhibhave sati duṣṭa ācāra tvāt śiṣṭa ācāraḥ eva nā upapadyate
translated: As for the conduct like marrying one's maternal uncle's daughter, etc., which has been cited, that is not proper conduct of the righteous when there is domination by lust, etc., because it is bad conduct.

original: yastvavigānenoktalakṣaṇaiḥ śiṣṭairācaryate tasya vedamūlatvāviśeṣāt smṛtyā saha tulyabalatvameva prāpnoti /
analyzed: yaḥ tu avigānena ukta lakṣaṇaiḥ śiṣṭaiḥ ācaryate tasya veda mūla tva aviśeṣāt smṛtyā saha tulya bala tvam eva prāpnoti
translated: But that which is practiced by the righteous whose characteristics have been mentioned without any doubt, that attains equality of strength with Smriti, because there is no difference in its being based on the Vedas.

analyzed: vibandhana anibandhanayoḥ tu anyat eva prayojanam upadiṣṭam
translated: And for the reasons of contradiction and non-contradiction, a different purpose has been taught.

original: na ca samācārasya smṛtivākyāntaritarūpsaya vedavākyānumānasaṃnikarṣakṛtaṃ balābalatvaṃ sidhyati //
analyzed: na ca samācārasya veda vākya anumāna saṃnikarṣa kṛtam balābala tvam sidhyati
translated: And the relative strength or weakness of conduct, which is in the form of being interspersed with Smriti statements and Vedic statements, is not established by proximity to the inference of Vedic statements.

analyzed: atrā ucyate atulya bala tvam tāvat veda ādīnām sūtra ārambha sārmathyāt eva avagamyate
translated: To this it is said: The inequality of strength of the Vedas, etc. is understood from the very purpose of beginning the sutra.

original: yadi hi tulyabalānyetāni syuḥ tadā virodhe vikalpaḥ sārmathyādeva siddhaḥ /
analyzed: yadi hi tulya balāni etāni syuḥ tadā virodhe vikalpaḥ sārmathyāt eva siddhaḥ
translated: For if these were of equal strength, then in case of conflict, option would be established by the very fact of their being equal.

analyzed: kim anena sūtreṇa iti tulya bala grahaṇam ca anarthakam syāt iti
translated: And the mention of equal strength would be meaningless.

analyzed: asmin api smṛteḥ upapadyate
translated: Even in this case, the greater strength of Smṛti than the Veda is possible.

analyzed: tatra liṅga prabhava tvam upapadyate iti uktam
translated: It has been said that the character of being based on inference is possible in that case.

analyzed: tena ayam eva  pakṣoyuktaḥ vastu
translated: Therefore, this🔽position is proper. The

analyzed: svatantra pakṣaḥ bhihitaḥ
translated: independent position has been stated.

original: sa pakṣaḥtadvidāṃ ca smṛtiśīleityetasmin sati durupapāda eveti /
analyzed: sa pakṣaḥ tad vidām ca smṛti śīle iti etasmin sati durupapādaḥ evā iti
translated: That position is for those who know the Smṛti and conduct. When this is the case, it is indeed difficult to establish.

analyzed: tasmāt veda liṅga prabhava tvam eva smṛtīnām nirdeṣataram iti
translated: Therefore, the fact that the Smṛtis originate from the indications of the Veda is the best explanation without fault.

analyzed: nanu ca evam api na upapadyate
translated: But even so, it is not possible.

original: kvacit smṛtyā śruterbādhadarśanāt yathā sāmānyena pravṛtto vaidikakarmādhikāraḥ smṛtyā upanītādipuruṣaviśeṣa evādhikriyate /
analyzed: kvacid smṛtyā śruteḥ bādha darśanāt yathā sāmānyena pravṛttaḥ vaidika karma adhikāraḥ smṛtyā upanīta ādi puruṣa viśeṣaḥ eva adhikriyate
translated: Because in some cases, the Smṛti is seen to contradict the Śruti, just as the Vedic injunction to perform rites, which applies in general, is restricted by the Smṛti to a particular person who has undergone initiation and so on.

analyzed: tathā saṃskāra eka deśena api ātma guṇa yoge sati viśiṣṭa phala abhidhānāt
translated: Similarly, because of the mention of a special result even when there is connection of the soul with a part of the purification.

original: tathā gāmālabheteti śruticodito 'pi govadhaḥ smārtapratiṣedhabalīyastvānna kriyate /
analyzed: tathā gām ālabheta iti śruti coditaḥ pi go vadhaḥ smārta pratiṣedha balīyaḥ tvāt na kriyate
translated: Similarly, even though the killing of a cow is enjoined by the Vedic text One should kill a cow, it is not done because the Smṛti prohibition is stronger.

original: tathāgnihotrādikaṃ coditajīvanopādhikaṃ karma dravyasādhyamapi na smārtacauryādipratiṣaddhenāpi dravyamārjayitvā tatkriyate /
analyzed: tathā agnihotra ādikam codita jīvana upādhikam karma dravya sādhyam api na smārta caurya ādi pratiṣaddhena api dravyam ārjayitvā tat kriyate
translated: Similarly, even though the rites such as the Agnihotra are enjoined for one who has the qualification of maintaining life, and are to be performed with substances, they are not performed by acquiring those substances through prohibited means such as theft according to the Smṛti.

analyzed: atas śrutyā smṛtiḥ bādhyate iti ayuktam uktam iti
translated: Therefore, it is not right to say that the Smṛti is contradicted by the Śruti.

analyzed: ucyate virodhe sata pramāṇānām balābala cintā yujyate
translated: It is said: When there is contradiction, it is proper to consider the relative strength of the means of knowledge.

original: yatra tu virodhābhāvaḥ tatra durbalopi naiva bādhyata iti /
analyzed: yatra tu virodha abhāvaḥ tatra durbala upi nā eva bādhyate iti
translated: But where there is no contradiction, even a weaker one is not contradicted.

original: yastāvadupanītasya karmādhikāraḥ saḥ śrutyā naiva virudhyate /
analyzed: yaḥ tāvat upanītasya karma adhikāraḥ saḥ śrutyā nā eva virudhyate
translated: As for the right to perform rites for one who has undergone initiation, that is not contradicted by the Śruti.

analyzed: upanayanasya veda grahaṇa artha tvāt
translated: Because the initiation is for the purpose of receiving the Veda,

analyzed: tasya ca karma artha tvāt
translated: and that is for the purpose of performing rites.

analyzed: na ca apūrva saṃyogam antareṇa pradhāna siddhiḥ
translated: And there is no establishment of the primary rite without the connection of something new.

original: yaccoktaṃ govardhestu śruticoditopi na kriyata iti /
analyzed: yat ca uktam govardheḥ tu śruti coditaḥ api na kriyate iti
translated: And what was said, that even what is enjoined by the Vedic text One should kill a cow is not done,

analyzed: tat api na kevalam smṛtyā
translated: that is not only by the Smṛti.

original: kintu mantravarṇācca 'mā gāḥ pramāpayāśvān pramāpaya' / ityādi /
analyzed: kintu mantra varṇāt ca mā gāḥ pramāpaya aśvān pramāpaya ityādi
translated: But also by the words of the mantra Do not deceive the cows, do not deceive the horses, and so on.

analyzed: atas smṛtyā śrutiḥ nā eva bādhyate
translated: Therefore, the Smṛti does not contradict the Śruti.

analyzed: kecid utsanna śākhā pūrvikām smṛtim āhuḥ
translated: Some say that the Smṛti is based on branches that have become extinct.

analyzed: tat ayuktam
translated: That is not correct.

original: tatra vicāryatekiṃ smaraṇātpūrvameva naṣṭāḥ śākhāḥ utottarakālamiti /
analyzed: tatra vicāryate kim smaraṇāt pūrvam eva naṣṭāḥ śākhāḥ uta uttara kālam iti
translated: It is considered whether the branches became extinct before the Smṛti or after.

analyzed: yāde pūrvam tatra smaraṇam na upapadyate
translated: If before, then the Smṛti is not possible there,

analyzed: vinaṣṭa tvāt
translated: because they are destroyed.

analyzed: pūrva vijñāna sadṛśa tvāt smṛteḥ
translated: Because the Smṛti is similar to the previous knowledge.

analyzed: yadi uttara kālam
translated: If after,

analyzed: tadā utsanna śākhā pūrvakatvam vaktum na yujyate
translated: then it is not proper to say that it is based on branches that have become extinct.

analyzed: tadānīm upalabhyamāna tvāt
translated: Because it is perceived at that time.

original: āpastamboktasyāpyayamabhiprāyaḥutsannāḥ kvacitkvaciddeśe na sarvatreti 'teṣāmutsannāḥ pāṭhāḥ prayogādanumīyante' /
analyzed: āpastamba uktasya api ayam abhiprāyaḥ utsannāḥ kvacid kvacid deśe na sarvatra iti teṣām utsannāḥ pāṭhāḥ prayogāt anumīyante
translated: This is also the intention of what is stated by Āpastamba: Their recitations that have become extinct are inferred from usage.

analyzed: iti atra api vyākhyā kartavyā
translated: Here also the explanation should be done.

analyzed: evam iyam dharma pramāṇa paribhāṣā uktā
translated: Thus this definition of the means of knowing Dharma has been stated.

analyzed: idānīm smṛtyā yat pramīyate tad abhidhāna artham āha
translated: Now, in order to state what is known by Smṛti, he says

analyzed: upanayanam brāhmaṇasya aṣṭame
translated: The initiation of a Brahmin is in the eighth year...

original: vedasya agnerācāryasya yamaniyamānāṃ vā samīpe nayanamupanayanam /
analyzed: vedasya agneḥ ācāryasya yama niyamānām vā samīpe nayanam upanayanam
translated: The bringing near of the Veda, of Agni, of the teacher, or of the restraints and observances, is initiation.

analyzed: tat aṣṭame varṣe
translated: That is in the eighth year.

analyzed: varṣa gaṇanā sārmathyāt
translated: Because of the difficulty in counting years.

analyzed: nityaḥ yam upanayana kālaḥ
translated: This is the permanent time for the initiation.

analyzed: kāmya āpad kalpayoḥ ūrdhvam abhidhānāt
translated: Because the optional and the substitute are mentioned later.

analyzed: kṣatriya vaiśyayoḥ ūrdhvam abhidhānāt śūdrasya eka jāti tvāt artha siddhasya api brāhmaṇa grahaṇasya jāti nimitta tva prasiddhi artham ārambhaḥ
translated: Because the initiation of the Kshatriya and Vaishya is mentioned later, and because the Shudra has only one caste, the beginning is made for the sake of establishing the fact that the mention of the Brahmin, though implied, is for the purpose of indicating caste, not for the purpose of enjoining it.

original: na ca dvijatvavat brāhmaṇatvaṃ kriyata iti /
analyzed: na ca dvija tva vat brāhmaṇa tvam kriyate iti
translated: And Brahminhood is not made like twice-born-hood.

original: tathā ca vakhiṣṭhaḥ 'prakṣālya pādau pāṇo cā maṇibandhanāt' / iti /
analyzed: tathā ca vakhiṣṭhaḥ prakṣālya pādau pāṇo ca maṇibandhanāt iti
translated: And thus Vasiṣṭha says, 'Having washed the feet and hands up to the wrists.'

analyzed: āsīnaḥ eva na anya avasthaḥ
translated: Only while sitting, not in any other posture.

original: tathāca vasiṣṭhaḥ'vrajan tiṣṭhan śayānaḥ praṇato vā nācāmet' / iti /🔽dākṣiṇaṃ bāhuṃ jānvormadhye kṛtvā /
analyzed: tathā ca vasiṣṭhaḥ vrajan tiṣṭhan śayānaḥ praṇataḥ vā na ācāmet iti  dākṣiṇam bāhum jānvoḥ madhye kṛtvā
translated: And thus Vasiṣṭha says, 'One should not sip water while walking, standing, lying down, or bowing.'🔽Having placed the right arm between the knees.

analyzed: yajñopavītā iti
translated: Wearing the sacred thread over the left shoulder.

original: yadi kadācit ayajñopavīti bhūtvāpyāste tathāpyācamane avaśyaṃ yajñopavītinā bhavitavyamiti /
analyzed: yadi kadācid a yajña upavīti bhūtvā api āste tathā api ācamane avaśyam yajña upavītinā bhavitavyam iti
translated: Even if one happens to be sitting without the sacred thread, one must necessarily have the sacred thread on while sipping water.

original: tathā cāpaspambaḥ'upāsane gurūṇāṃ vṛddhānāmatithīnāṃ home japyakarmaṇi bhojana ācamane svādhyāye ca yajñopavīti syāt' / iti /
analyzed: tathā ca āpaspambaḥ upāsane gurūṇām vṛddhānām atithīnām home japya karmaṇi bhojane ācamane svādhyāye ca yajña upavīti syāt iti
translated: And thus Āpastamba says, 'One should have the sacred thread on during worship of elders, the aged, and guests, during oblations, muttering of prayers, eating, sipping water, and recitation of one's own Veda.'

analyzed: ācamana aṅga tvena anya yajñopavīta utpādana artham vā
translated: Or for the purpose of producing another sacred thread as an accessory of sipping water.

analyzed: tathā ca vasiṣṭhaḥ
translated: And thus Vasiṣṭha says:

analyzed: snātakānām tu nityam syāt antarvāsaḥ tathā uttaram
translated: But for the snātakas, the inner garment and the upper garment should always be worn,

analyzed: yajñopavīte yaṣṭiḥ sa udakaḥ ca kamaṇḍaluḥ
translated: with the sacred thread, a staff, and a water pot with water.

analyzed: iti
translated: Thus.

analyzed: maṇiḥ yasmin deśe badhyate sa maṇibandhaḥ
translated: The place where the gem is tied is the gem-binding.

analyzed: tasmāt ā maṇibandhanāt pāṇī prakṣālya vāgyataḥ tūrṣṇīm hṛdaya spṛśaḥ hṛdayaṃgamāḥ
translated: From that, having washed the hands up to the gem-binding, silently, with restrained speech, touching the heart, pleasing the heart.

analyzed: apām parimāṇa artham idam
translated: This is for the purpose of measuring the water.

analyzed: māṣa nimajjana mātrāḥ tāvatyaḥ bhavanti
translated: They are as many as a māṣa (a kind of bean) would submerge.

original: tathācāhośanā 'māṣanimajjanamātrā hṛdayaṃgamā bhavanti' / iti /🔽triścaturvetyatra vikalpo vyavasthitaḥ yadā 'āpaḥ punantu' /
analyzed: tathā ca āha uśanāḥ māṣa nimajjana mātrāḥ hṛdayaṃgamāḥ bhavanti iti  tris catuḥ vā iti atra vikalpaḥ vyavasthitaḥ yadā āpaḥ punantu
translated: And thus Auśanasā says: They are pleasing to the heart as much as a māṣa would submerge.

analyzed: ityādi mantram uktvā ācamyate tadā catuḥ
translated: As for three or four times, the option is fixed: when one sips water after reciting the mantra beginning with May the waters purify, then four times.

analyzed: anyatra tris iti
translated: Elsewhere, three times.

original: abgrahaṇaṃ gomūtrādinivṛttyarthaṃ teṣāṃ śuddhihetutvasāmānyādgrahaṇaṃ mā bhūditi /
analyzed: ap grahaṇam go mūtra ādi nivṛtti artham teṣām śuddhi hetu tva sāmānyāt grahaṇam mā bhūt iti
translated: The mention of water is for the purpose of excluding cow's urine and so on, so that they should not be included because of the commonality of being the cause of purification.

analyzed: uṣṇa buddha uda phena kaṣāya ādi varjana artham vā
translated: Or for the purpose of avoiding hot, frothy, astringent, etc.

analyzed: pibet iti vaktavye ācāmet iti guru sūtra karaṇam vidhi antara upasaṅgraha artham
translated: Although it should be said one should drink, the use of the word ācamya (sipping) in the authoritative text is for the purpose of including other injunctions.

original: tatra tūśanā'ha 'dakṣiṇaṃ hastatalaṃ gokarṇākāraṃ vinyasya brāhmeṇa tīrthenāśabdaṃ pibedṛgyajuḥsāmavedān dhyāyan' / iti //
analyzed: tatra tu uśanā āha dakṣiṇam hasta talam gokarṇa ākāram vinyasya brāhmeṇa tīrthena a śabdam pibet ṛk yajuḥ sāma vedān dhyāyan iti
translated: There, Auśanasā says: Having placed the right palm in the shape of a cow's ear, one should drink silently with the brahma-tīrtha, meditating on the Ṛg, Yajur, and Sāma Vedas.🔽One should wipe (the lips) twice...

analyzed: dvis parimṛjyāt
translated: He should rub (the cup) twice round.

analyzed: prakṛta ap oṣṭhau
translated: The lips as they are.

analyzed: atra anukta tvāt
translated: Because it is not mentioned here.

analyzed: smṛti antara darśanāt ca
translated: And because of the observation of another Smriti.

analyzed: brāhmeṇa eva tīrthena
translated: With the very Brahmanical way.

analyzed: pariti upasargaḥ vidhi antara upasaṃgraha arthaḥ
translated: The prefix 'pari' is for including another injunction.

original: tatra tūktaṃ kaṇvena'atharvavedetihāsapurāṇāni dhyāyan brāhmeṇa tīrthenoṣṭhayoḥ salomapradeśaṃ mṛjyāt' / iti //
analyzed: tatra tu uktam kaṇvena atharvaveda itihāsa purāṇāni dhyāyan brāhmeṇa tīrthena uṣṭhayoḥ saloma pradeśam mṛjyāt iti
translated: There it is said by Kanva: 'Then, meditating on the Atharvaveda, Itihasa and Puranas, one should wipe the hair-covered part of the lips with the Brahmanical way.'

analyzed: pādau ca abhyukṣet
translated: And one should sprinkle the feet.

analyzed: cakārāt mukham ca
translated: From the word 'ca' (and), the face also.

analyzed: abhyupasargaḥ vidhi antara upasaṃgraha arthaḥ
translated: The prefix 'abhi' is for including another injunction.

analyzed: tatra āha bhārgavaḥ oṣṭhau parimṛjyāt tatas mukham
translated: There it is said by Bhargava: 'Then one should wipe the lips, then the face,

analyzed: parimṛjet agnāndhyāyam pādau abhyukṣet viṣṇum
translated: meditating on Agni. Then one should sprinkle the feet, meditating on Vishnu.'

analyzed: khāni ca upaspṛśet śīrṣaṇyāni  khāni śīrṣaṇyāni nayana nāsikā karṇāni
translated: And one should touch the cavities connected with the head.

analyzed: cakārāt hṛdayam ca
translated: The cavities connected with the head are the eyes, nose, and ears.🔽From the word 'ca' (and), the heart also.

analyzed: tathā ca manuḥ
translated: And so says Manu:

analyzed: tris ācāmet apaḥ pūrvam dvis unmṛjyāt tatas mukham
translated: One should first sip water thrice, then wipe the mouth twice,

analyzed: khāni ca upaspṛśet adbhiḥ ātmānam hṛdayam śiraḥ
translated: and touch the cavities with water, the body, heart, and head.

analyzed: iti
translated: Thus.

original: upopasargo vidhyantaropasaṃgrahārthaḥ tannośanā 'aṅguṣṭhopakaniṣṭikābhyāṃ nayane🔽candrādityau dhyātvā tata upaspṛśya tarjanyaṅguṣṭhābhyāṃ nāsikāvakāśau prāṇān dhyātvā
analyzed: upa upasargaḥ vidhi antara upasaṃgraha arthaḥ tat na uśanāḥ aṅguṣṭha upakaniṣṭikābhyām nayane  candra ādityau dhyātvā tatas upaspṛśya tarjanī aṅguṣṭhābhyām nāsikā avakāśau prāṇān dhyātvā
translated: The prefix upa has the sense of including another injunction. Uśanas says, With the thumb and little finger, one should touch the eyes,🔽meditating on the sun and moon. Then, having touched water, with the index finger and thumb, one should touch the nostrils, meditating on the vital airs,

original: tata upaspṛśya kaniṣṭhikāṅguṣṭhābhyāṃ karṇau diśo dhyātvā tata upaspṛśyāṅguṣṭhena
analyzed: tatas upaspṛśya kaniṣṭhikā aṅguṣṭhābhyām karṇau diśaḥ dhyātvā tatas upaspṛśya aṅguṣṭhena
translated: and then touch water. With the little finger and thumb, one should touch the ears, meditating on the directions, and then touch water. With the thumb alone,

analyzed: kevalena hṛdayam upaspṛśet ātmānam dhyāyan iti
translated: one should touch the heart, meditating on the self.

analyzed: mūrdhani ca dadyāt
translated: And one should place (water) on the head.

original: mūrdhani cet vaktavye dadyāditi grahaṇaṃ sarvāṅgulyartham /
analyzed: mūrdhani ced vaktavye dadyāt iti grahaṇam sarva aṅguli artham
translated: If it is to be said on the head, the word should place is for all the fingers.

original: tathāca smṛtyantaraṃ 'sarvāṅgulibhiḥ śriyaṃ dhyātvā mūrdhani prakṣipet' / iti /
analyzed: tathā ca smṛti antaram sarva aṅgulibhiḥ śriyam dhyātvā mūrdhani prakṣipet iti
translated: And thus another Smṛti says, Having meditated on Śrī with all the fingers, one should place (water) on the head.

analyzed: cakārāt savye ca pāṇau
translated: By the word ca (and), (it is meant) in the left hand also.

original: tathā ca vasiṣṭhaḥ'mūrdhani ca dadyātsavye pāṇau' / iti /
analyzed: tathā ca vasiṣṭhaḥ mūrdhani ca dadyāt savye pāṇau iti
translated: And thus Vasiṣṭha says, One should place (water) on the head and in the left hand.

analyzed: kṣatriya vaiśyayoḥ api etat eva ācamanam viśeṣa anabhidhānāt strī śūdrau ca sakṛt sakṛt
translated: For the Kṣatriya and Vaiśya also, this alone is the Ācamana, because no distinction is mentioned, and for women and Śūdras, once each.

original: iti smṛtyantarābhidhānāt strīśūdrayośca sakṛtpānāt sakṛdoṣṭhasparśanācca śuddhirdraṣṭavyā atrānuktāpi //
analyzed: iti smṛti antara abhidhānāt strī śūdrayoḥ ca sakṛt pānāt sakṛt oṣṭha sparśanāt ca śuddhiḥ draṣṭavyā atra anuktā api
translated: And because it is stated in another Smriti, it should be understood that for women and Sudras, purification is by drinking once and by touching the lips once, even though it is not mentioned here.

analyzed: na kevalam ucchiṣṭa sparśaḥ eva ācamanam
translated: And not only is the touching of the leavings a cause of sipping water.

analyzed: anyat api ācamana nimittam idānīm āha
translated: Now he states another cause of sipping water:

analyzed: suptvā bhuktvā kṣutvā ca punar
translated: Having slept, having eaten, having sneezed, again...

analyzed: punargrahaṇam ādau ante ca ācamanam kuryāt iti evamartham
translated: The word 'again' is for the purpose of stating that one should sip water at the beginning and at the end.

analyzed: cakārāt snātvā ruditvā ca
translated: From the word 'ca' (and), after bathing and weeping.

original: tathā ca vasiṣṭhaḥ 'suptvā bhuktvā kṣutvā snātvā pītvā ruditvā cācāntaḥ punarācāmet' / iti //
analyzed: tathā ca vasiṣṭhaḥ suptvā bhuktvā kṣutvā snātvā pītvā ruditvā ca ācāntaḥ punar ācāmet iti
translated: And thus Vasistha: 'Having slept, having eaten, having sneezed, having bathed, having drunk, having wept, having sipped water, one should sip water again.'

original: tatra kṣutasyāniyatakālatvāt ādāvaśakyamācamanamiti cet tatrāpi nityaprāyatyārtha ārambhaḥ /
analyzed: tatra kṣutasya aniyata kāla tvāt ādau aśakyam ācamanam iti ced tatra api nitya prāyatyā arthaḥ ārambhaḥ
translated: If it is argued that since sneezing is not of fixed time, it is impossible to sip water at the beginning, even there the beginning is for the purpose of always being pure.

analyzed: yathā āha āpastambaḥ muhūrtam api śakti viṣaye na aprayataḥ tiṣṭhet iti
translated: As Apastamba says: 'One should not remain impure even for a muhurta in a place where there is the possibility.'

analyzed: svāpa ādau prayatasya api ācamanam ārambha sārmathyāt
translated: And for one who is pure while sleeping etc., the sipping of water is due to the difficulty of beginning.

original: atastatrādāvante cācamanaṃ kuryāt tatra bhojane kecidādāvapi dvirācamanamicchanti /
analyzed: atas tatra ādau ante ca ācamanam kuryāt tatra bhojane kecid ādau api dvis ācamanam icchanti
translated: Therefore one should sip water at the beginning and at the end there. In eating, some desire to sip water twice at the beginning also.

analyzed: tathā ca āpastambaḥ bhokṣyamāṇaḥ tu prayataḥ dvis ācāmet iti
translated: And in the same way Apastamba (says), 'But when about to eat, he shall sip water twice, being pure.'

analyzed: anye svāpa ādau ante eva dvis ācamanam icchanti yathā āha uśanā
translated: Others desire that the twice sipping of water is only at the end of sleep, etc., as (says) Ahas.

original: 'suptvā bhuktvā kṣutvā snātvā pītvā ruditvā cācāntaḥ punarācāmeddvi' / iti /
analyzed: suptvā bhuktvā kṣutvā snātvā pītvā ruditvā ca ācāntaḥ punar ācāmet dvi iti
translated: 'Having slept, having eaten, having sneezed, having bathed, having drunk, having wept, and having sipped water, he shall again sip water twice.'

original: evaṃ ca bhojane ādāvante cca dvirācamanaṃ svāpādāvekamante ca dviḥ /
analyzed: evam ca bhojane ādau ante ca dvis ācamanam svāpa ādau ekam ante ca dvis
translated: Thus, at eating, twice at the beginning and at the end; at sleep, etc., once at the end; twice.

analyzed: kṣutasya aniyata tvāt ante eva dvis iti siddhāntaḥ
translated: The settled conclusion is that, as to sneezing, it is at the end, twice.

original: idānīnucchiṣṭasaṃśleṣe aśucitve prāpte āha🔽dantaśliṣṭeṣu dantavadanyatra jihvābhimarśanāt //🔽daśanāntaralagneṣu bhakṣyabhojyāvayaveṣu dantavat anucchiṣṭo bhavatītyarthaḥ /
analyzed: idānīn ucchiṣṭa saṃśleṣe aśuci tve prāpte āha  danta śliṣṭeṣu danta vat anyatra jihvā abhimarśanāt  daśana antara lagneṣu bhakṣya bhojya avayaveṣu danta vat anucchiṣṭaḥ bhavati iti arthaḥ
translated: Now, when the question arises as to whether one becomes impure by contact with what remains of food in the mouth, he (the author) says:🔽In the case of particles of food sticking to the teeth, one is not impure, except when the tongue touches them, as in the case of the teeth.🔽The meaning is that in the case of particles of food sticking between the teeth, one is not impure, as in the case of the teeth.

analyzed: na ced jihvayā saṃspṛśyante
translated: But if they are touched by the tongue.

analyzed: atra api
translated: Here also,

original: prākcyuterityeke // / //🔽satyapi jihvābhimarśane yāvat svasthānānna cyavanti tāvacchucirityeke manyante //
analyzed: prāk cyuteḥ iti eke  sati api jihvā abhimarśane yāvat sva sthānāt na cyavanti tāvat śuciḥ iti eke manyante
translated: Some say that it is so before they fall off.🔽Some think that even when they are touched by the tongue, as long as they do not fall from their place, one is pure.

analyzed: cyuteṣu āsrāva vat vidyāt nigiran eva tat śuciḥ
translated: When they fall off, one should know that he is pure only by swallowing them, as in the case of saliva.

original: cyuteṣu āsye yajjalaṃ tadāsrāve yadvadvijātīyāt tannigiran śucacireva bhavati /
analyzed: cyuteṣu āsye yat jalam tat āsrāve yadvat vijātīyāt tat nigiran śuca cir eva bhavati
translated: When water falls from the mouth, one becomes pure by swallowing it, just as by swallowing something of a different class.

analyzed: ācamana śaṅkā
translated: There is no doubt about sipping water.

analyzed: na asti iti arthaḥ
translated: The meaning is that there is no doubt.

analyzed: evam ca āsrāvam api nigiran śuciḥ eva bhavati
translated: And thus, by swallowing even saliva, one becomes pure.

original: kutaḥ cyuteṣu nigiran śuciriti vaktavye āsrāvavadvidyādityārambhāt /
analyzed: kutas cyuteṣu nigiran śuciḥ iti vaktavye āsrāvavat vidyāt iti ārambhāt
translated: Why is it said that one becomes pure by swallowing when water falls from the mouth, when the beginning is made with one should know it to be like saliva?

analyzed: gautamaḥ tu danta śliṣṭānām sati jihvā abhimarśane aśuciḥ bhavati iti
translated: But Gautama says that when the teeth are touched and the tongue is licked, one becomes impure.

analyzed: anya matam tu prāk cyuteḥ iti
translated: But the opinion of others is that it is before the fall.

analyzed: saḥ yam vyavasthita vikalpaḥ
translated: This is a settled option.

analyzed: karma anuṣṭhāna adhikṛtasya ācamana namanyasya na iti
translated: For one who is entitled to perform rites, there is no sipping, for others there is.

original: yathocchiṣṭāvayavo bahirbhūtaḥ aśucitvamāpādayati tadvadāsrāvasyāpi prāpta āha🔽na mukhyā vipruṣa ucchiṣṭaṃ kurvanti na cedaṅge nipatanti // / //
analyzed: yathā ucchiṣṭa avayavaḥ bahis bhūtaḥ aśuci tvam āpādayati tadvat āsrāvasya api prāptaḥ āha  na mukhyāḥ vipruṣaḥ ucchiṣṭam kurvanti na ced aṅge nipatanti
translated: Just as a part of the leavings, when outside, causes impurity, so also saliva, when it reaches the lips, causes impurity. He says:🔽The main drops do not make one impure with leavings if they do not fall on the body.

original: mukhe bhavā mukhyāḥ vipruṣa āsrābāvayavāḥ te mantrayamāṇasya vinirgatā nāprāyatyaṃ janayanti yadyaṅge stanodarādau na nipatanti /
analyzed: mukhe bhavāḥ mukhyāḥ vipruṣaḥ āsrāba avayavāḥ te mantrayamāṇasya vinirgatāḥ na āprāyatyam janayanti yadi aṅge stana udara ādau na nipatanti
translated: The main drops, which are parts of saliva, coming out of the mouth of one who is talking, do not cause impurity if they do not fall on the body, on the breast, belly, etc.

original: niśabdo niścayārthaḥ ato niścayena yadyaṅge patanti tadānīmevocchiṣṭaṃ janayanti nāśaṅkāmātreṇeti /
analyzed: niśabdaḥ niścaya arthaḥ atas niścayena yadi aṅge patanti tadānīm eva ucchiṣṭam janayanti na āśaṅkā mātreṇa iti
translated: The word 'ni' (in the compound 'niścaye') means certainty. Therefore, if they fall on a limb with certainty, then alone they produce impurity, not merely by suspicion.

analyzed: evam ca ucchiṣṭa avayavaḥ yatra kutracid nipatan ucchiṣṭam janayati
translated: And thus, a part of the impure, falling anywhere, produces impurity.

analyzed: āsrāvaḥ ṅgaḥ eva iti siddhāntaḥ
translated: The final conclusion is that the discharge is only a limb.

analyzed: sarva śauca artham idam adhunā ucyate  lepa gandha apakarṣaṇe śaucam amedhya liptasya
translated: This is now being said for the purpose of all purification:🔽Purification is the removal of stains and smells from what is smeared with impure substances.

original: lepagandhayorapanayane kṛte amedhyaliptasya amedhyasambaddhasya śucitvaṃ bhavati /
analyzed: lepa gandhayoḥ apanayane kṛte amedhya liptasya amedhya sambaddhasya śuci tvam bhavati
translated: When the removal of stains and smells is done, one becomes pure who is smeared with impure substances, who is connected with impure substances.

analyzed: amedhya śabdena dvādaśa malāḥ ucyante
translated: By the word 'impure substances', the twelve impurities are meant.

analyzed: yathā āha manuḥ
translated: As Manu says:

analyzed: vasā śuklam asṛk majjā mūtra viṣ ghrāṇa karṇa viṣ
translated: Fat, semen, marrow, urine, feces, nasal discharge, earwax,

original: śleṣmāśru dūṣikā svedo dvādaśaite nṛṇāṃ malāḥ //🔽anabhivyaktagandhānāṃ śleṣmādīnāṃ lepamātradarśanāt lepagrahaṇam /
analyzed: śleṣmā aśru dūṣikā svedaḥ dvādaśā ete nṛṇām malāḥ  anabhivyakta gandhānām śleṣma ādīnām lepa mātra darśanāt lepa grahaṇam
translated: phlegm, tears, saliva, sweat - these twelve are the impurities of humans.🔽The word 'lepa' (stain) is used because the unmanifest smells like phlegm etc. are only seen as stains.

analyzed: mūtra ādīnām lepa anupalabdheḥ gandha mātra upalabdheḥ ca gandha grahaṇam
translated: The word 'gandha' (smell) is used because the stains of urine etc. are not perceived, and only the smell is perceived.

original: śaucādhikāre punaḥ śaucagrahaṇaṃ taijasādīnāmapi lepagandhāpanayanayādeva śaucamityevamartham //
analyzed: śauca adhikāre punar śauca grahaṇam taijasa ādīnām api śaucam iti evamartham
translated: The mention of purification again in the section on purification is for the purpose of stating that the purification of things made of metal etc. is by merely removing the stain and smell.

original: tat kena kartavyamityata āha🔽tadadbhiḥ pūrvaṃ mṛtā ca // / //
analyzed: tat kena kartavyam iti atas āha  tad adbhiḥ pūrvam mṛtā ca
translated: By whom should that be done? Therefore it is said:🔽That is to be done first with water, and then with earth...

analyzed: iti bhinna phala tvena upadeśāt jābāla śrutau api anyatamam āruhya iti an uktvā etān āruhya iti samuccaya abhiprāyeṇa ukta tvāt
translated: Thus, because of the teaching of different fruits, and in the Jābāla Śruti also, because of the statement with the intention of including all, saying having ascended these without saying having ascended any one,

original: brahmalokaprāpterapi samuccayaphalatvenopadiṣṭatvāt jābālaśrutāvapi prādhānyena pūrvaṃ samuccayapakṣasyaivābhihitatvāt /

translated: and because the attainment of the world of Brahman is also taught as the fruit of combination, and in the Jābāla Śruti also, the combination view is stated first as the primary view.

analyzed: sarve pi kramaśas

analyzed: iti asmin manu vākye pi śabdasya samuccaya artha tvāt
translated: In this Manu passage, because of the word api (also) having the meaning of combination.

original: āpastambavākye 'pi teṣu sarveṣviti bahuvacanāt naikasminneva vartamānaḥ kiṃ tu sarveṣveva vartamāna ityabhiprāyeṇoktatvāt /
analyzed: āpastamba vākye teṣu sarveṣu iti bahuvacanāt na ekasmin eva vartamānaḥ kim tu sarveṣu eva vartamānaḥ iti abhiprāyeṇa ukta tvāt
translated: And in the Āpastamba passage also, because of the plural in all of them, it is said with the intention that it is not present in only one, but is present in all.

analyzed: ṛṇa traya śruteḥ api yathārthe eva upapadyamāna tvāt

analyzed: pūrva prajñā ca eti śruteḥ api vidyā abhiprāyeṇa upapadyamāna tvāt
translated: And because the statement and previous wisdom is also logically possible with reference to knowledge.

original: yāvajjīvaśruterapigṛhī vanaṃ praviśedyadi gṛhameva kāmayeta tadā yāvajjīvasagnihotraṃ juhuyātiti jābālaśrutivākye anityatvadarśanāt /
analyzed: yāvajjīvaśruteḥ api gṛhī vanam praviśet yadi gṛham eva kāmayeta tadā yāvajjīvasagnihotram juhuyāt iti jābāla śruti vākye anitya tva darśanāt
translated: Even in the case of the injunction to study the Veda throughout life, if one who has studied it enters the forest and then desires to return to the householder's life, he should perform the Agnihotra throughout life, as shown by the Jābāla Śruti text.

analyzed: asmin pakṣe vyatthāna śruteḥ api sutarām upapadyamāna tvāt
translated: In this view, even the mention of the option is very reasonable.

analyzed: caturtham āyuṣaḥ bhāgam iti anena api manunā samuccaya pakṣam eva āśritya ukta tvāt
translated: And because Manu also, in the verse one fourth of life for studentship etc., has stated it on the basis of the view of combination only.

analyzed: samuccaya pakṣaḥ eva śreyān iti  atas eva vikalpa bādha pakṣau para mata tvena upanyastau
translated: Therefore, the view of combination is better.🔽For this very reason, the views of option and prohibition have been presented as the opinion of others.

translated: And thus, the statements beginning with one should follow the one he desires should be seen as stated from the perspective of the teacher of option.

original: asamartho yaḥ samuccayānuṣṭhāne andhapaṅgutvādidoṣeṇa niḥsvatvādinā vā tena vikalpapakṣo 'pyāśrayaṇīyaḥ ityabhiprāyeṇa bruvata ityarthasiddhasyāpyupanyāsaḥ
analyzed: asamarthaḥ yaḥ samuccaya anuṣṭhāne andha paṅgu tva ādi doṣeṇa niḥsva tva ādinā vā tena vikalpa pakṣaḥ pi āśrayaṇīyaḥ iti abhiprāyeṇa bruvataḥ iti arthasiddhasya api upanyāsaḥ
translated: The meaning is that it is stated by one who thinks that one who is unable to perform the combination, due to defects such as blindness and lameness, or due to being penniless, should also adopt the view of option.

analyzed: athavā ayaḥ dhyā ātma jñānī tena vikalpa pakṣaḥ āśrayaṇīyaḥ
translated: Or, one who knows the inner self should adopt the view of option.

analyzed: itareṇa samuccaya pakṣaḥ iti
translated: The other should adopt the view of combination.

analyzed: kutas anuṣṭhānasya vijñāna utpattiḥ prayojanam
translated: Why? The purpose of the performance is the production of knowledge.

analyzed: ke punar te āśramāḥ iti atas āha

analyzed: brahmacaryam carati iti

analyzed: brahmaṇaḥ eva vā viṣaye niḥspṛhaḥ carati iti

analyzed: brahmacārī

analyzed: gṛham patnī tad saṃyogāt agṛhasthaḥ

analyzed: bhikṣā śīla tva ādi bhakṣuḥ

analyzed: visamāse eṣām eva

original: pṛthaktvajñāpanārthaḥ /🔽yathā'hośanā'dvau brahmacāriṇāvupakurvāṇo naiṣṭhikaśceti /🔽dvau vaikhānasau sapatnīko vipatnīkaśceti /
analyzed: pṛthaktva jñāpana arthaḥ  yathā āha uśanāḥ dvau brahmacāriṇau upakurvāṇaḥ naiṣṭhikaḥ ca iti  dvau vaikhānasau sapatnīkaḥ vipatnīkaḥ ca iti

analyzed: dvau saṃnyāsinau bhikṣu sanyāsī veda sanyāsī ca iti
translated: There are two renunciates, the mendicant renunciate and the Vedic renunciate.

translated: The householder is of many kinds, being divided into Śāli, Yāvaka, etc.

analyzed: iti atra vaikhānasa varjana arthaḥ krama bhedaḥ

translated: The celibate, the householder, the mendicant - this assembly is of not less than ten.

analyzed: iti

analyzed: kecid tu

analyzed: teṣām gṛhasthaḥ yoniḥ a prajana tvāt itareṣām

analyzed: a prajana tvāt itareṣām brahmacārī ādīnām

analyzed: vaikhānasa arthā hetu uktiḥ

translated: Because for the celibate student, celibacy is established by the very fact of protecting celibacy, and because there is no injunction of continence for one who eats after sunset.

analyzed: evam ca vaikhānasasya sapatnīka tva pakṣe brahmacarya rakṣaṇam kartavyam
translated: And thus, even in the case of the forest-dweller having a wife, celibacy must be protected.

analyzed: adhikārāt eva siddhe teṣām

analyzed: tathā ca śātātapaḥ

analyzed: teṣām jātāni apatyāni caṇḍālaiḥ saha vāsayet

analyzed: tatra caṇḍālāḥ bhavanti
translated: And there, they become untouchables.

original: pratyavasitāḥ pratinivṛttāḥ ye parivrājakatāpasāḥ naiṣṭhikavaikhānasāḥ tasmātteṣāṃ jātānyapatyāni caṇḍālaiḥsahavāsayedrājā grāmo vetyarthaḥ
analyzed: pratyavasitāḥ pratinivṛttāḥ ye parivrājaka tāpasāḥ naiṣṭhika vaikhānasāḥ tasmāt teṣām jātāni apatyāni caṇḍālaiḥ sahavāsayet rājā grāmaḥ vā iti arthaḥ
translated: Those who have fallen back, who have turned away, who are wandering ascetics, who are life-long anchorites, the king should make their offspring born from that live together with the untouchables, the meaning is that the village should do so.

original: idānīmāśramadharmeṣu krameṇa vaktavyeṣu prāpteṣu sarvāśramasāmyādupakurvāṇasya pūrvamuktvā naiṣṭhikasya krameṇa prāptaṃ vaktumāha
analyzed: idānīm āśrama dharmeṣu krameṇa vaktavyeṣu prāpteṣu sarva āśrama sāmyāt upakurvāṇasya pūrvam uktvā naiṣṭhikasya krameṇa prāptam vaktum āha
translated: Now, when the duties of the stages of life are to be stated in order, having come up, having stated first the duties of the life-long student, which are common to all stages of life, he states in order the duties of the life-long anchorite, which have come up.

analyzed: tatra uktam brahmacāriṇaḥ

analyzed: tatra upanayana prakareṇa yat agni indhana ādi uktam tat asya api bhavati iti atideśaḥ
translated: The extension is that what was stated in the section on initiation, such as kindling the sacred fire, etc., is also for him.

original: nanu ca naiṣṭikasyaivedaṃ nopakurvāṇasyeti kathaṃ jñāyata iti /
analyzed: nanu ca naiṣṭikasya eva idam na upakurvāṇasya iti katham jñāyate iti

analyzed: ucyate upakurvāṇasya ukta tvāt

analyzed: gṛhastha bhikṣu vaikhānasānām vakṣyamāṇa tvāt
translated: Because the duties of the householder, the monk, and the anchorite are going to be stated.

analyzed: naiṣṭikasya eva bhavati iti

original: tarhi brahmacārigrahaṇaṃ kimartamiti cet yenopakurvāṇavratamanuṣṭhitaṃ tasyaiva🔽naiṣṭhikatvasyādhikāra ityevamartham /

analyzed: atideśāt upakurvāṇa vratam eva naiṣṭhikasya api anuṣṭātavyam iti uktvā idānīm asya viśeṣa vidhim āha

analyzed: ācārya pāratantryam tad citta anuvidhāyi tvam ā maraṇāt kartavyam
translated: The dependence on the teacher, the conformity with his mind, should be done until death.

analyzed: kiṃca  guroḥ karma śeṣeṇa japet

translated: And thus japa alone is his special means of attaining dharma.

analyzed: tathā ca manuḥ

translated: The service of those three is said to be the highest austerity.

analyzed: iti  guru abhāve tad apatye vṛttiḥ
translated: Thus.🔽When the teacher is not available, one should serve his offspring.

analyzed: guroḥ abhāve tad apatye śuśrūṣā
translated: When the teacher is not available, one should serve his offspring.

analyzed: adhyāpayituḥ abhāve tad apatye śuśrūṣā iti niyama artham  guru grahaṇam samāna jātīya apatya grahaṇa artham
translated: In the absence of the teacher, it is for the purpose of enjoining service to his son.🔽The word 'guru' is used to include the son of the same caste.

analyzed: apatya grahaṇam bhāryā nivṛtti artham
translated: The word 'son' is used to exclude the wife.

analyzed: tad abhāve vṛddhe sabrahmacāriṇi agnau vā

analyzed: tad abhāve sabrahmacāriṇim samāna caraṇe
translated: In their absence, to a fellow student who is of the same status.

analyzed: tad abhāve agnau
translated: In their absence, to the sacred fire.

analyzed: agneḥ śuśrūṣā jyotiḥ rūpasya agneḥ dhyānam
translated: The service to the sacred fire is the meditation on the luminous form of the fire.

analyzed: kim punar asya āśramasya phalam iti atas āha  evaṃvṛttaḥ brahma lokam avāpnoti jita indriyaḥ
translated: What, then, is the fruit of this stage of life? To this he says🔽One who conducts himself thus, and has conquered the senses, attains the world of Brahman.

analyzed: brahmacarya rakṣaṇa upadeśāt upastha indriyasya ukta tvāt idam cakṣuḥ ādi viṣayam draṣṭavyam
translated: This should be understood to refer to the senses of sight etc., since the sense of procreation has already been mentioned by the injunction to preserve celibacy.

analyzed: yathā āha manuḥ
translated: As Manu says:

analyzed: śrutvā spṛṣṭvā ca dṛṣṭvā ca bhuktvā ghrātvā ca yaḥ

translated: He who is neither elated nor depressed is to be known as one who has conquered the senses.

analyzed: gṛhasthasya brahmacarya rakṣaṇam
